When I first saw the announcement for this game I was excited. Then I found out it was a souls-like and I was no longer interested. I'm fine with souls games but sparingly. A friend urged me to try the demo and that was the end of it.

This game is fantastic. Full stop.

First, technical:

I'm running on a 4080 Super/Ryzen 7800X3D. The game has the typical UE stutter. It's infrequent but it happens enough to be noticeable. A couple times it stuttered and got me killed. Also, I got 4 crashes while playing the game.

Those hiccups aside, I played at 4k maxed settings with DLSS Qualiity and the game hovered in the 120s-130s fps. Absent the occasional stutter, the game is smooth and responsive and looks fantastic.

I'd played a couple hours of the game before the update and had thought I was playing the game on Normal. It wasn't until I was at the end of the game that I realized I was playing on Expert. lol. Suffice it to say, if you play this game on expert, be ready for a challenge. It's brutal at times. BUT, Khazan's mobility (one of my biggest issues with souls-likes) is great. He's quick and his dodges are great. I hate the rolling of souls games, so this was a breath of fresh air. Brink dodges are incredibly satisfying in this game, the controls are snappy and responsive, and the combat can be quite fast depending on your build. 

The audio is another great thing about this game. If you have headphones, it sounds great, but if you have a home theater setup with 3d audiio, hearing sounds from ceiling speakers is awesome.

There are two bosses that crossed the line from challenging to cheap/frustrating. Magic users. No satisfaction in beating them, only relief, so be ready for that. Only one boss had a camera issue for me and that was a boss that was huge. You could only target one area of it and if you get to close, the camera becomes a second boss for you to fight. This was poorly done and should have been addressed.

The story is good, but grim. Another reason I don't gravitate to souls games is they tend to be grimdark. That's a "Me" issue, obviously, but if you like that sort of thing, you'll be happy here. If you're like me and not much for grim stories, you may still enjoy it, as I did. Greatly. 

The game is fun. There are plenty of things to find, loot to acquire, and secrets to uncover via hidden portals. Enemy types are cool and well animated, though optional bosses are simply recycled main bosses you fought earlier in the game. Not a huge deal but worth noting. 

Conclusion, IMO First Berserker Khazan is peak. The combat, story, visuals, sound, and fun factor are all there in spades, and although the technical hiccups are annoying and SHOULD BE ADDRESSED, they are not so egregious as to ruin the experience. I loved this game and I hope you do as well. 

Thank you for reading.

I'd call it the Anime version of Dark Souls 3. It took me a while to really enjoy and appreciate the game in view of the fact that I have long list of souls like games played already. What I truly have to point out is the quality in production value. 

Despite having a similar medieval fantasy setting, it boasts Anime graphics, good combat, great detail and a ridiculous creative amount on armor pieces, which I find is the best feature by the way. Positive and negative summary below. 

THE GOOD STUFF

+ Just like with AI Limit, this game boast an incredible beautiful Anime style game design which is very refreshing and fun! 
+ Great visual presentation and plenty of cutscenes, from intro to backstory. Some boss fights have good cutscenes too. This is one of the points where I say you can clearly see the effort and production value. They also put effort in storytelling and trying to convey an actual background. This is also where I give credit 
+ Easy UX/UI and great overview on the skill tree. Plus, there are plenty of special skills for each weapon type
+ Combat is fun
+ I actually like the "functional level design" that is a mix of linear and free roaming. Compared to other souls like games, I don't get lost at all. It's not as confusing as similar titles. This is another plus point. Also, plenty of loot
However, at the same time the level design in terms of atmosphere and environment is pretty dull and nothing special. More below. 
+ A crazy amount of armor pieces, from top to bottom. You can mix up your appearance and make a weapon look like whatever weapon from the same category you like. THIS is a must for all souls like games. This feature is similar to NIOH and Assassins Creed games. 
+ The Korean approach and design philosophy is very detailed. I can sense they love souls like games. They respect the legacy games such as Dark Souls.
 
Minor things I don't like or fall under the negative sides: 

	- You can use only one main weapon‚Ä¶ No swapping like in other souls like games, in which you can instantly change between two weapons or weapons slots. In this game: NO. You're restricted to only ONE weapon slot. Choose carefully. Quite annoying to be honest.. I LOVE TO swap weapons instantly, because that's how I always done it. You have to go to the menu and select gear - that's where you can select one main weapon. Note: If you get ATTACKED while on the menu and trying to change gear, the whole menu will disappear. 

The main headquarters or home base (crevice) feels confusing. The design of pathways is confusing as hell. Not only that, it has basically TWO worlds where you need to traverse between. Either serves different purposes. One is for NPCs and blacksmith, the other world is to travel to other locations. WHY NOT COMBINE BOTH into one?! I didn't like it from the start and till now, I still hate it! 

- LEVEL DESIGN: Castles and other areas can inherent insane details on the floor, statues etc. The overall design looks very good. Functional level design as described above is alright but in terms of atmosphere, It doesn't really spark an interest to explore. We got the SAME stuff and atmosphere:

Castles, temples, plenty of caves and dungeons that look very, very, similar and dull. Missions often take place at night or dusk. It's just so boring and I understand when people say "levels look the same" because the environment and atmosphere IS. Personally this is the biggest WEAK POINT. There are a few castle areas where I'd say "ok this looks different and NEW" but in general everything looks exactly like you've seen before.

- I hate to be THE GUY, but since it is my personal and honest review, and how I feel about it, I got to say the title strikes amusement. "THE FIRST BERSERKER KHAZAN" - Couldn't it just be "KHAZAN"? Or "BERSERKER KHAZAN". 

My verdict: GET THE GAME, especially if you've played any other souls like games, it's that simple. You'll feel familiar and get used to quick. On the other hand, the game can be newcomer friendly too. If you like fantasy action games, it's also for you. Give it a try.

I actually bought First Berserker: Khazan when it first came out, played a few hours, and wasn't feeling it. The dodging and combat timing just weren't clicking with me, so I put it down and kind of forgot about it.

Recently, I decided to give it another shot, and I'm genuinely so glad I did.

Once I got used to how the combat flows, everything suddenly made a lot more sense, and it became really fun. The more skills I unlocked, the more my whole playstyle changed, and it kept the game from ever feeling repetitive. It's one of those games that rewards you for sticking with it, and you can actually feel yourself getting better as you go.

The world design is absolutely gorgeous, too. And the bosses? I ended up loving most of them some for their looks, some for their mechanics, and some just for how satisfying it was to finally beat them.

I ended up 100% completing the game, which is crazy considering how I felt at the start. But honestly, it turned into one of the most enjoyable Soulslikes I've played. If you tried it before and bounced off like I did, give it another chance. It was totally worth it.

üéÄI received this game as a gift from my daughter who is nordic and the fact that it draws deeply from norse mythology makes it feel even more special to me.

I honestly cannot remember the last time a game made me feel every hit so physically. In this, Khazan has a rare gift because it manages to make even the air before a fight feel heavy. There are no layers of systems piled on top of each other, no attempt to look more complex than it is. Just you, a weapon, and that annoyingly honest feeling of knowing that if you mess up, it is your fault. 
The game offers a ton of builds and full sets that are normal, rare, epic and legendary, even upgradeable, and a lot of skills depending on your playstyle.
What surprised me the most though is the rhythm, because it is neither frantic nor slow, it is just right. The game forces you to breathe at its pace, almost as if it wants to teach you how to fight in its world instead of adapting to yours. And when you finally start to understand, when the movements become instinctive like parries and counterattacks, that satisfaction kicks in that only truly well made games can give you.
The narrative and atmosphere go straight to the point. No wordy detours, no useless layers because everything is built to make you feel a world that has no time to waste. Cutscenes are short but sharp, and the way the story locks into the gameplay gives the sense that every step forward is earned.

There are some truly wonderful environments, one even reminds me of Anor Londo from Dark Souls while another reminds me of the dungeons in Elden Ring, and there are also huge castles to explore, collectibles to find, and texts that explain the lore in more detail.
I also really appreciated the care in the details and worldbuilding. I am not just talking about the artistic direction but about the way the environments communicate what has happened in those places, not only beautiful in the classic sense but also interesting. Every location feels like it is telling a story.
On top of that, the game on ultra settings is incredibly smooth and well optimized. I did not encounter a single bug or performance problem, none at all. On the technical side it is exceptional work.
The game is quite rough and difficult and that is exactly what gives it character. It is a game that is not afraid to show its seams because what truly remains is the experience, not the polish.
I usually don‚Äôt like using two handed weapons because they are too fast and I can‚Äôt savor every hit, but with my greatsword build the female berserker becomes a true earthquake with charged attacks and every swing is as heavy as a mountain.
Honestly, it is exactly what I look for in a game like this and I hope for a sequel or even a trilogy.

As a huge fan of the Souls series, Elden Ring, and Sekiro, I was immediately drawn to First Berserker: Khazan. What hooked me from the start was its combat system, which, while not a traditional Soulslike, delivers a refreshing twist on the genre.

The combat is more dynamic and combo-oriented, yet it still keeps the familiar stamina management that punishes reckless button-mashing. Parrying and dodging feel incredibly satisfying. As a Sekiro veteran, I naturally gravitated toward parrying, but the game allows you to rely entirely on dodging if you prefer. That freedom to shape your own approach is one of my favorite things about it.

The boss fights are a real highlight. They‚Äôre challenging, especially on Expert, but always fair. Like any good Soulslike, success comes from learning patterns and adjusting your playstyle, sometimes going full offense, other times taking a more cautious approach. I didn't encounter a single "bad" boss; all were solid, and a few were genuinely outstanding.

The soundtrack is excellent, especially during certain boss encounters where the music perfectly enhances the tension and atmosphere.

As for the story, I was a bit skeptical at first, but the more I progressed, the more curious I became. It‚Äôs not the deepest narrative I‚Äôve experienced, but it‚Äôs engaging enough to keep you invested.

My main criticism is the level design. It can feel repetitive and lacking in variety, sometimes making the environments look a bit dull. It doesn‚Äôt ruin the experience, but it‚Äôs definitely the weakest aspect of the game.

Overall, I‚Äôd place Khazan just below Lies of P in my personal ranking. For me, and many others, Lies of P is the best modern Soulslike thanks to its story, combat, music, level design, and art direction. Khazan isn‚Äôt far behind, though.

If you're a Soulslike fan, I highly recommend starting on Expert difficulty, which clearly feels like the intended experience. You‚Äôll get frustrated, you'll have fun, but you‚Äôll definitely feel accomplished.
If you're more of a casual player, Normal or even Easy will still let you enjoy the game without the steep learning curve.

I rarely write reviews, but this game gave so many different feelings I just have to put it somewhere, might as well here. I think that TFB: Khazan is really solid game with a lot of virtues, but also has some flaws, unfortunately some quite unforgiving. Kind of feels like there was a lot of diffrent "borrowed" ideas from multiple games...

I would like to split it all into three sections, things I realy like (PROS), things I realy don't like(CONS) and things that I do not really know how to feel about(IDK).

PROS:
+ Combat - like holyyy this feels really satisfying. The animations all flawless, combos are fluent, attacks have appropriate weight to them (greatsword hell yeaa). Skill tree points actually change a lot, unlocking new powerful attacks is rewarding. This is the biggest asset of the game and this is what makes you keep going. Counters feel great, there are different types of it, dodges too. Skills hit really hard, like really hard. SEXY.
+ BERSERKER!!! - Khazan is a badass, his armor is badass, weapon is badass, he is shredded, has a badass voice acting (japanese version) and he is pissed off. Perfect berskerer. I love the character and big ass swords. Feels good to help him get his revenge.
+ Boss encounters - this is what "souls-likes" are all about, the fights are pleasant, bosses differ a lot, have some cool mechanics and designs. Some of them have some enjoyable backstories too. No spoiler this is just some cool shit you gotta kill.
+ Equipment - different weapon and armor looks awesome and the perks that they provide are really meaningful
+ Visuals - the game looks absolutely gorgeous and runs really smoothly. (4070ti)
+ SFX - sounds are crisp and well balanced. Truly enriching the combat, helps out with counterattacks for boss patterns, directional sound helps with collectibles.


CONS:
- Level design - This is the worst part of the game, already mentioned by many players. I have to agree. The levels even though created with beautiful assets, fell really repetetive, the way the world is designed does not really feel like actual world. The main "base" is too big, a lot of unnecessary running and confusion. Not a single location feels memorable (outside boss encounters). If you visited one basement and one cave, you have seen it all, it will just be the same everywhere. There are some small exceptions with somewhat nice view's but that is it unfortunatelly. Enemies outside bosses are well designed, but it does not change the fact that you are killing the same mobs in (what fells like) the same corridors, over and over and that gets me to the next point.
- Length of the game/content - The game is just too long for what it has to offer. The combat is amazing sure, but in the half of the game you literally know all it has to offer, besides some late game armor set skills. I was really excited at the begining of the game, but then the longer I played, it was really just going through some boring parts to get to another cool boss. Same corridors, same mobs, same "traps", meaningless loot.
- Crafting & looting - even though armors & weapon you will get is really great, the way the game is serving it to you seems lacking. You find a lot of different equipment parts through out the game, but what realy only matters are scrolls (blueprints) for the sets so you can collect it and then craft it. Unfortunetly, crafting is boring, there no super rare materials, just materials you get from farming over and over the same boss (or buying from one of the vendors). There is no resources managment pretty much. The level of the equipment makes some shitty whites better then your super legendary equipment in no time. The only thing that stands out are cool perks from sets. 


IDK:
? Weapon variety - Three weapon types is not a lot, but I think it is better to have obli three, but really good, than 10 shitty ones I guess. Just wish it was the same attitude in all aspects. 
? One weapon at the time - You can only have one weapon at the time because you need all the perks, this is how the game was designed, I am not sure how could that be enchanced.
? Story & characters - The story is simple, there is nothing mind blowing really, but looks like a good background for all the slashing & smashing. Characters are somewhat unique, it is just that there is not enough story and interaction showed in the game to really care about what is happening. I wish there was a little bit more of an introduction to the story, little more relationship building between the characters, I want to know more just so all that fighting actually feel more personal.
? No item requirements - It is cool you can wear everything you have in your inventory, but it does kind of kill the purpose of stats, there is just some small changes between how much damage you deal,how much damage you can take and how long will it take to make you stop swining/blocking.

Difficulty - I find normal mode too easy, most of the bosses were I first tried and it just kind of sad, because I wanted to work a little harder, then I changed the difficulty to expert and from being really tanky and dealing crazy damage now I did no damage and was being one shotted by almost everything. It is really personal, but I wish there was some "middleground".


All in all, fun game, hopefully there will be sequel that enchances the game, because it really has some great potential.

I'm not sure about the whole elements system (their debuffs in particular). If you get afflicted by one, you're basically forced to stop pressuring the boss, which is very important for some bosses in this game.
The whole secret to this game is learning how to parry attacks and understanding that enemies are very vulnerable after a parry. Almost all of them allow you to combo them until you exhaust and stun them, which in turn lets you deal even more damage (if you stun them without a parry, that window will be much shorter).

Some bosses don't allow you to parry them (some mages) and need a different approach. On first glance they might seem pretty unbalanced and unfun, until you figure it out. I still hated it, but in this game you need to adapt to some bosses. If you're unwilling to use consumables (buffs), skills, etc., then you're basically handicapping yourself, and that's on you if you're struggling with something in this game.
Another game like this is Nioh, where if you use everything available to you, you'll breeze through the bosses without much trouble.

The only advice I want to give to people who struggle with the game is to understand that your equipment matters a lot. Some pieces even define your playstyle, which makes a major difference for some encounters. That's why sub-quests are important as well, since you'll get a lot of stuff that will make it easier to progress further. If you have trouble with a specific boss, there's usually a set that can help you if you think you can't defeat the boss with your skill.

Khazan wants to combine combat aspects from Nioh and Sekiro:
From Nioh: Three different weapon types with own skill trees and a phantom form which is similar to the guardian spirits in Nioh.
From Sekiro: Parry and deflect mechanics.

Overall, this game reminds me a little bit of Darksiders and I wouldn't say that it's a bad game if they weren't those bosses with their HP bars.

Yes, bosses have WAY TOO MUCH HP. I don't have any problem fighting a boss over and over again. 

In Elden Ring, it took me over 100 tries to beat Malenia.
In Nioh, it took me over 100 tries to beat side mission Tachibana Muneshige.
In Sekiro, I died 50+ times against Genichiro Ashina.

Yet, I managed to keep up my motivation and beat them because it was still fun. Nothing interrupted the flow of these fights. You knew that the only reason a fight took so long was your own lack of skill which you could improve.

In The First Berserker: Khazan, I faced the final boss, Ozma. It is the first boss ever in a souls-like game which I dropped voluntarily after about 20 attempts, because it just wasn't worth my time. It's not like he's that difficult to adapt to. It's rather that it takes eons of time to reduce his health to zero due to flying, certain spell animations and other disengage tools - even if you counter or reflect his attacks perfectly and pull out the best combo damage output possible during his stagger phase. By repeating this annoying first phase, you barely get to see his second/third phase and upon death, you have to repeat this shit again. That's not fun at all if there is no way to speed the first phase up with your own skill.

What I described is also true for a lot of other bosses like Hismar. Instead of giving those bosses tons of HP, reduce it and increase their damage in exchange to make those fights more fast paced instead.

I don't understand how people can compare this game to Nioh or Sekiro. 
In Nioh, you have hard boss fights, too, but once you know the move set of your enemy, you can play more aggressively and finish most bosses off in less than one or two minutes.
In Sekiro, you can beat the first phase of Genichiro in less than one minute if you put pressure the right way.

At first glance, Khazan looks a lot like Nioh. You've got a mechanically impeccable melee combat foundation featuring your choice of weapons, a heavy emphasis on stamina management and stance breaking, a Soulslike level structure, and an RPG layer that feels simultaneously perfunctory and hilariously over-designed, with an indiscriminate shower of Diablo loot to sift through. At second glance, Khazan looks *exactly* like Nioh, almost feature-for-feature, except kind of less cool in every way.

It's hard to pinpoint exactly what feels so mediocre about Khazan because, aside from the well-manicured combat fundamentals, mediocrity kind of permeates every aspect of it. To put it shortly, it has very little personality. Visually, it's a very unexciting introduction to the DFO universe, both artistically and technically, featuring a lot of generic fantasy biomes washed in dull palettes and garish color-grading. Khazan himself is a pretty flaccid lead character, and weirdly, going berserk isn't really featured in either story or gameplay. He mostly just seems bored most of the time. The story is a nothingburger to a hilarious degree, but I actually found that part kind of charming. ("It's Rangkus's twin brother, Brangkus!") The voice cast, weirdly, is excellent, despite the fact that the script gives them nothing to work with. They're all bought in regardless - my hat's off to all of you. The soundtrack... Look, I don't keep up with AI-generated music, but if operatic orchestral slop is out in the wild, I kind of imagine this is what it would sound like.

So yeah, Khazan is disinterested in leveraging any aspect of creative direction to establish an identity for itself. But the real problem is that, despite the solid combat mechanics, the levels aren't any fun to play at all. This is primarily because they're trivially easy most of the time. Encounters are an artless mishmash of mostly toothless enemies that demand nothing and teach you nothing, and man, there's so damn many of them. Every level runs about twice as long as it merits, only occasionally seasoned with any bespoke scripting beyond the kickable ladders and one-way door unlocks that have been systematized to the point of feeling completely prosaic. Also, they feature the worst crit path layout I can remember in a game, which somehow manages to make me feel like I'm stoned trying to navigate it despite being almost always completely linear. Like, there's a level where the crit path routes you off the main street, into the first floor of a house, out the back door, around a U-turn, up some stairs, back into the same house, just so you can reach a staircase that only spans the second and third floors, cause the construction crew got bored with that staircase halfway through or something. The complexity of the layout never matches the actual complexity of your routing decisions; it's just convolution for convolution's sake. I'm not exaggerating when I say that navigating these mostly linear levels is, somehow, the most challenging thing you do in any Khazan level before you reach the boss fight.

In short, these levels really suck. And they're long, too. This pattern is established early and doesn't really change, leaving you feeling constantly blueballed waiting to get to the bosses, which are.... far and away the best thing about the game, actually! Now at this point, I've played so many Soulslikes that the quirks of their combat have a tendency to irritate me. Gone are the days when I can I die while trying to drink from a full stash of flasks (sorry, "Netherworld Energy") without getting at least a little grumpy. But even allowing for that, the boss fights here pretty consistently entertain, even when they're being annoying. There are 17 in total, and only two or three of them were duds. Even though they're pretty visually plain compared to what Fromsoft can do these days, the level of care put into tuning every attack is evident. The final boss, in particular, gets nearly perfect marks. I do think they're tuned too stiff overall, especially considering the low difficulty of the rest of the game. None of them do anything unfair, but I'd have enjoyed the journey more if only *some* of them took an hour-plus of committed attempts, instead of nearly all of them.

On that note - the difficulty settings in general are wacky. I started on Normal and found the game pointlessly easy, eventually discovering this was a postgame patch and that Hard was the original normal difficulty. So I switched to Hard and started over after a few stages. On Hard, the game is still pretty easy, except for the routine skullfucking you get from bosses. There isn't really a happy medium to be found here and it kind of sucks.

The other thing breaking up the monotony of the levels is your intermittent engagement with the game's RPG systems. For better or worse, Khazan has just copied Nioh's loot system whole cloth, warts and all. Sets are still kind of fun to collect, because the set bonuses actually do something. Parameters on the non-set items still feel like the devs trolling you (i.e "-4.2% guard stamina damage while in critical health"). Trying to actually engage in earnest with all the information the game throws at you will still give you brain damage. It's just as well you don't, because almost none of it actually matters. In practice, you pick which set bonuses you want, get them to a semi-decent level, and ignore everything else. Farming a specific set is now a little less painful, since you can restart a mission from the boss checkpoint as often as you want. The game isn't stingy at all about crafting set pieces either, once you find the recipe. I'm pretty unimpressed at the lack of initiative to iterate more meaningfully and improve on Nioh's obvious flaws in this area, but the gear does its basic job.

And the skill tree... Well, Khazan has one of *those* skill trees. You've seen them before. You know, where you think something like "My biggest problem seems to be stamina management," and then you take all of the skills related to stamina, and then your biggest problem is still stamina management. Every skill is parameterized with conditional clauses  that imply build specificity (i.e. "Gain a small amount of Spirit after breaking an enemy's stance") But ultimately, they're all templated to be generically, marginally useful; the boundaries you get to play inside here are tiny. None of them will significantly change the gamefeel or the way you play. The only real decision to make here is which Spirit skills (resource-gated special abilities on an arts palette) you take, and you will eventually be able to get all of them. In short, it's like most mediocre skill trees, inoffensive and kinda pointless.

I don't really know how to rate Khazan as a strict yes/no. Objectively speaking, it's not a bad game, even occasionally great, but I also kinda wish I had spent my time playing something else. I guess I'd put it like this: Khazan has no aspirations beyond being a Decent Soulslike for People Who Are Obsessed With Soulslikes. If that's you, then you'll probably have a good time playing it, and also, you have probably already bought it. If it's not you... Well, you've probably got better games to play than Khazan.

The best way for me to describe Khazan is "mid."
It does a lot of things decently, but doesn't really stand out. It's fine, but there are so many games that overshadow Khazan, it's hard to recommend unless you are craving an acceptable nioh-like.

Of course, the closest game to compare Khazan to is Nioh 2, as the combat is much faster and combo focused using specific weapon types, rather than the more deliberate pace of Souls/Lies of P combat.  Loot is also uses random drops and levels, and everything is mission based. However, while Nioh 2 had over 10 different weapon types, Khazan has only 3, so you better hope you like one of them.

The Nioh 2 inspiration goes further in some rather bad ways as well. Enemies are often scratching at the ground for no reason (except to get backstabbed), massive exposition dumps after a boss kills, NPCs who do nothing aside from stand at the start of a mission to say a few lines.
NPCs and the story in general are handled quite poorly. Civilians just stand there quietly weeping, major NPCs have nothing interesting to say, all of them blurring together, often babbling about "their beloved" or some other person you'll never meet (alive).
The most common lines you'll hear are "Gasp! You too?" and "Why?! Aaaaahhh!" 

The graphics are, fine. Sadly, the colorful outdoor regions are quickly overshadowed by: ruined town, ruined castle, ruined laboratory, ruined church, ruined mine, ruined theater, etc. Most of them also use the same beige and grey stonework with washed out lighting. The "ruined" aspect is so overdone, it can feel like the level designers wanted to leave no hall, no corner without a healthy heaping of rubble.

Combat is, fine. If you played Nioh, you're most of the way there. Oh, no magic and only one dedicated ranged attack. Still Khazan, moves smoothly and has lots of offensive and defensive options. 
Unless there is any kind of height different. In which case Khazan can't jump, can barely attack higher or lower than waist height, and drops like a stone.
(On base difficulty, NG) Game difficulty is generally on the low side. If you've played a decent number of these games, you'll regularly 1-2 shot bosses. If you're new to these games, the game is very gentle, with free skill respecs, easily accessible stat repecs, and generous support for boss fights.

Khazan isn't a bad game, it's just a decent game in a space with a lot of competition.

Khazan wants to combine combat aspects from Nioh and Sekiro:
From Nioh: Three different weapon types with own skill trees and a phantom form which is similar to the guardian spirits in Nioh.
From Sekiro: Parry and deflect mechanics.

Overall, this game reminds me a little bit of Darksiders and I wouldn't say that it's a bad game if they weren't those bosses with their HP bars.

Yes, bosses have WAY TOO MUCH HP. I don't have any problem fighting a boss over and over again. 

In Elden Ring, it took me over 100 tries to beat Malenia.
In Nioh, it took me over 100 tries to beat side mission Tachibana Muneshige.
In Sekiro, I died 50+ times against Genichiro Ashina.

Yet, I managed to keep up my motivation and beat them because it was still fun. Nothing interrupted the flow of these fights. You knew that the only reason a fight took so long was your own lack of skill which you could improve.

In The First Berserker: Khazan, I faced the final boss, Ozma. It is the first boss ever in a souls-like game which I dropped voluntarily after about 20 attempts, because it just wasn't worth my time. It's not like he's that difficult to adapt to. It's rather that it takes eons of time to reduce his health to zero due to flying, certain spell animations and other disengage tools - even if you counter or reflect his attacks perfectly and pull out the best combo damage output possible during his stagger phase. By repeating this annoying first phase, you barely get to see his second/third phase and upon death, you have to repeat this shit again. That's not fun at all if there is no way to speed the first phase up with your own skill.

What I described is also true for a lot of other bosses like Hismar. Instead of giving those bosses tons of HP, reduce it and increase their damage in exchange to make those fights more fast paced instead.

I don't understand how people can compare this game to Nioh or Sekiro. 
In Nioh, you have hard boss fights, too, but once you know the move set of your enemy, you can play more aggressively and finish most bosses off in less than one or two minutes.
In Sekiro, you can beat the first phase of Genichiro in less than one minute if you put pressure the right way.

At first glance, Khazan looks a lot like Nioh. You've got a mechanically impeccable melee combat foundation featuring your choice of weapons, a heavy emphasis on stamina management and stance breaking, a Soulslike level structure, and an RPG layer that feels simultaneously perfunctory and hilariously over-designed, with an indiscriminate shower of Diablo loot to sift through. At second glance, Khazan looks *exactly* like Nioh, almost feature-for-feature, except kind of less cool in every way.

It's hard to pinpoint exactly what feels so mediocre about Khazan because, aside from the well-manicured combat fundamentals, mediocrity kind of permeates every aspect of it. To put it shortly, it has very little personality. Visually, it's a very unexciting introduction to the DFO universe, both artistically and technically, featuring a lot of generic fantasy biomes washed in dull palettes and garish color-grading. Khazan himself is a pretty flaccid lead character, and weirdly, going berserk isn't really featured in either story or gameplay. He mostly just seems bored most of the time. The story is a nothingburger to a hilarious degree, but I actually found that part kind of charming. ("It's Rangkus's twin brother, Brangkus!") The voice cast, weirdly, is excellent, despite the fact that the script gives them nothing to work with. They're all bought in regardless - my hat's off to all of you. The soundtrack... Look, I don't keep up with AI-generated music, but if operatic orchestral slop is out in the wild, I kind of imagine this is what it would sound like.

So yeah, Khazan is disinterested in leveraging any aspect of creative direction to establish an identity for itself. But the real problem is that, despite the solid combat mechanics, the levels aren't any fun to play at all. This is primarily because they're trivially easy most of the time. Encounters are an artless mishmash of mostly toothless enemies that demand nothing and teach you nothing, and man, there's so damn many of them. Every level runs about twice as long as it merits, only occasionally seasoned with any bespoke scripting beyond the kickable ladders and one-way door unlocks that have been systematized to the point of feeling completely prosaic. Also, they feature the worst crit path layout I can remember in a game, which somehow manages to make me feel like I'm stoned trying to navigate it despite being almost always completely linear. Like, there's a level where the crit path routes you off the main street, into the first floor of a house, out the back door, around a U-turn, up some stairs, back into the same house, just so you can reach a staircase that only spans the second and third floors, cause the construction crew got bored with that staircase halfway through or something. The complexity of the layout never matches the actual complexity of your routing decisions; it's just convolution for convolution's sake. I'm not exaggerating when I say that navigating these mostly linear levels is, somehow, the most challenging thing you do in any Khazan level before you reach the boss fight.

In short, these levels really suck. And they're long, too. This pattern is established early and doesn't really change, leaving you feeling constantly blueballed waiting to get to the bosses, which are.... far and away the best thing about the game, actually! Now at this point, I've played so many Soulslikes that the quirks of their combat have a tendency to irritate me. Gone are the days when I can I die while trying to drink from a full stash of flasks (sorry, "Netherworld Energy") without getting at least a little grumpy. But even allowing for that, the boss fights here pretty consistently entertain, even when they're being annoying. There are 17 in total, and only two or three of them were duds. Even though they're pretty visually plain compared to what Fromsoft can do these days, the level of care put into tuning every attack is evident. The final boss, in particular, gets nearly perfect marks. I do think they're tuned too stiff overall, especially considering the low difficulty of the rest of the game. None of them do anything unfair, but I'd have enjoyed the journey more if only *some* of them took an hour-plus of committed attempts, instead of nearly all of them.

On that note - the difficulty settings in general are wacky. I started on Normal and found the game pointlessly easy, eventually discovering this was a postgame patch and that Hard was the original normal difficulty. So I switched to Hard and started over after a few stages. On Hard, the game is still pretty easy, except for the routine skullfucking you get from bosses. There isn't really a happy medium to be found here and it kind of sucks.

The other thing breaking up the monotony of the levels is your intermittent engagement with the game's RPG systems. For better or worse, Khazan has just copied Nioh's loot system whole cloth, warts and all. Sets are still kind of fun to collect, because the set bonuses actually do something. Parameters on the non-set items still feel like the devs trolling you (i.e "-4.2% guard stamina damage while in critical health"). Trying to actually engage in earnest with all the information the game throws at you will still give you brain damage. It's just as well you don't, because almost none of it actually matters. In practice, you pick which set bonuses you want, get them to a semi-decent level, and ignore everything else. Farming a specific set is now a little less painful, since you can restart a mission from the boss checkpoint as often as you want. The game isn't stingy at all about crafting set pieces either, once you find the recipe. I'm pretty unimpressed at the lack of initiative to iterate more meaningfully and improve on Nioh's obvious flaws in this area, but the gear does its basic job.

And the skill tree... Well, Khazan has one of *those* skill trees. You've seen them before. You know, where you think something like "My biggest problem seems to be stamina management," and then you take all of the skills related to stamina, and then your biggest problem is still stamina management. Every skill is parameterized with conditional clauses  that imply build specificity (i.e. "Gain a small amount of Spirit after breaking an enemy's stance") But ultimately, they're all templated to be generically, marginally useful; the boundaries you get to play inside here are tiny. None of them will significantly change the gamefeel or the way you play. The only real decision to make here is which Spirit skills (resource-gated special abilities on an arts palette) you take, and you will eventually be able to get all of them. In short, it's like most mediocre skill trees, inoffensive and kinda pointless.

I don't really know how to rate Khazan as a strict yes/no. Objectively speaking, it's not a bad game, even occasionally great, but I also kinda wish I had spent my time playing something else. I guess I'd put it like this: Khazan has no aspirations beyond being a Decent Soulslike for People Who Are Obsessed With Soulslikes. If that's you, then you'll probably have a good time playing it, and also, you have probably already bought it. If it's not you... Well, you've probably got better games to play than Khazan.

The best way for me to describe Khazan is "mid."
It does a lot of things decently, but doesn't really stand out. It's fine, but there are so many games that overshadow Khazan, it's hard to recommend unless you are craving an acceptable nioh-like.

Of course, the closest game to compare Khazan to is Nioh 2, as the combat is much faster and combo focused using specific weapon types, rather than the more deliberate pace of Souls/Lies of P combat.  Loot is also uses random drops and levels, and everything is mission based. However, while Nioh 2 had over 10 different weapon types, Khazan has only 3, so you better hope you like one of them.

The Nioh 2 inspiration goes further in some rather bad ways as well. Enemies are often scratching at the ground for no reason (except to get backstabbed), massive exposition dumps after a boss kills, NPCs who do nothing aside from stand at the start of a mission to say a few lines.
NPCs and the story in general are handled quite poorly. Civilians just stand there quietly weeping, major NPCs have nothing interesting to say, all of them blurring together, often babbling about "their beloved" or some other person you'll never meet (alive).
The most common lines you'll hear are "Gasp! You too?" and "Why?! Aaaaahhh!" 

The graphics are, fine. Sadly, the colorful outdoor regions are quickly overshadowed by: ruined town, ruined castle, ruined laboratory, ruined church, ruined mine, ruined theater, etc. Most of them also use the same beige and grey stonework with washed out lighting. The "ruined" aspect is so overdone, it can feel like the level designers wanted to leave no hall, no corner without a healthy heaping of rubble.

Combat is, fine. If you played Nioh, you're most of the way there. Oh, no magic and only one dedicated ranged attack. Still Khazan, moves smoothly and has lots of offensive and defensive options. 
Unless there is any kind of height different. In which case Khazan can't jump, can barely attack higher or lower than waist height, and drops like a stone.
(On base difficulty, NG) Game difficulty is generally on the low side. If you've played a decent number of these games, you'll regularly 1-2 shot bosses. If you're new to these games, the game is very gentle, with free skill respecs, easily accessible stat repecs, and generous support for boss fights.

Khazan isn't a bad game, it's just a decent game in a space with a lot of competition.

I would recommend this game only if you seek for a mindless challenge and don't care about anything else. Below are some things which I don't like about the game.

There are several archetypes of levels in the game such as castle, cave, village etc, and all of them are extremely generic, I think "generic" is the best word to describe the game. Everything looks exactly the same and I can't tell a difference between a castle at the beginning vs at the end of the game. If you played any Dark Souls game you'll be able to remember any location by it's screenshot but it's not the case in this game. It's just the same bland greyed-out generic castle/village/cave and there are absolutely no memorable places in the game.

I don't really like the progression system: you gain like 0.4-0.7 percent in attributes or +3 AR increase which is basically nothing when the weapon AR is 400+
You complete missions, gain some "memories" things and increase the hp/poise damage by 1% at best. Wow what a generosity

The game desperately wants to be hard and full of cliches from any souls-like:
- If you see an item somewhere in a room be sure to be ambushed by multiple mobs which appear from nowhere
- If walk on a narrow bridge be sure to get attacked by an enemy who would try to push you off the bridge
- Like a half of glowing red items/chests are traps
- Tons of mobs, especially towards the end of the game

Sometimes I had weird input drops, especially on the heal/use item button when you press it while not in an animation or animation recovery but the character just does nothing.

Also I don't really like the difficulty approach in this game. The "intended" difficulty is "expert" and I have the only question - really? Is this really what the game is intended to be? Bosses have HUGE amount of health and it takes ridiculous amount of time to get them down while they destroy you in 3 hits. You may expect to commit some massive damage when you deplete the poise bar like in Sekiro but no - the damage amount is laughable. Maybe somebody would enjoy such a compelling gameplay but personally for me at some point it became just dull and boring. The weird thing is that if you switch the difficulty mode from "expert" to "normal" then the game becomes ridiculously easy removing any challenge whatsoever. I have no idea what's happening on the easy mode, maybe bosses are damaging themselves.
